awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE: Network for Integrating Bioinformatics into Life Sciences Education (NIBLSE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Nebraska at Omaha has received a Research Coordination Network - Undergraduate Biology Education award for their project entitled Network for Integrating Bioinformatics into Life Sciences Education (NIBLSE). The long-term goal of this project is to establish bioinformatics as an essential component of undergraduate life sciences curricula nationwide. The field of bioinformatics, which uses techniques from computer science to store, manage, and analyze large biological data sets, has arisen to meet the challenges associated with such large data sets.  It is now an important interdisciplinary field that is central to studying many aspects of biology, yet it is not an integral part of most biology curricula nationwide.  The current project is informed by the results of the successful conference held by the PI team for their RCN-UBE Incubator project (DBI-134559).

In order to achieve full integration of bioinformatics into undergraduate life sciences education, NIBLSE is establishing a permanent network of investigators committed to this goal. The Leadership Team and Steering Committee are using the literature and their collective expertise to identify, vet, and refine a set of bioinformatics core competencies for inclusion in life sciences curricula.  They are also identifying and vetting assessment tools that align with the core competencies and that will facilitate educational research related to the integration of bioinformatics into biology curricula.  Finally, they are developing systems to organize and simplify dissemination of curricular materials, assessment tools, and professional development resources.  The materials and resources developed by the  network are having a broad impact on undergraduate education in the life sciences by enabling educators nationwide to effectively apply bioinformatics knowledge and skills to their teaching and research.  This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RESEARCH COORD NETWK IN BIO SC
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The field of bioinformatics, which uses techniques from computer science to store, manage, integrate, and analyze biological data, has arisen to meet the challenges associated with extracting meaning from complex datasets. Such datasets are increasingly available to life scientists, thanks to continuing advancements in high-throughput experimental methods and related computational technologies. Bioinformatics is now an important interdisciplinary field that is central to studying many aspects of biology. Despite the increasing importance of bioinformatics, however, there is a general lack of integration of bioinformatics concepts and competencies in undergraduate life sciences education. This gap prevents students from harnessing the full potential of their biology education and limits their postgraduate career opportunities.

The long-term goal of NIBLSE is to achieve the full integration of bioinformatics into undergraduate life sciences education, thereby addressing the gap described above. By bringing together a large group of committed faculty who are interested in this topic to share experiences and ideas, we have provided new resources, new professional development opportunities, and contributed to educational research.  This has made life science faculty better educators and directly benefitted students. NIBLSE products and publications will help guide institutions and departments as they move forward with integrating bioinformatics into their life sciences curricula. The vetted curricular materials and assessments, available to all interested parties, will help interested instructors integrate bioinformatics into their courses.

Intellectual Merit—The intellectual merit of the NIBLSE project is to establish a network of investigators to facilitate the communication and collaboration thata ensures full integration of bioinformatics into life science education nationwide. 

 

Broader Impacts—The NIBLSE network broadly impacts undergraduate education in the life sciences. The network enables educators across the nation develop and deploy bioinfornatics skills in teaching and research. The NIBLSE network and the student body served by the results of NIBLSE resources are diverse.  The netowrk knowledge and skills to their teaching and research. The RCN-UBE Incubator continues to reach educators in more than 20 universities that collectively enroll approximately more than 450,000 students per year across the United States. NIBLSE membership continues to include educators from universities with diverse student bodies, and the composition and participation of these colleagues and their students will guarantee continued diversity in the network as it expands and is sustained well beyond this sixth year. In addition, NIBLSE includes both computer and life scientists representing various disciplines.

 


 

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2021
Modified by: William E Tapprich
